results.title: New Dragon Gate Inn = Dragon Inn
results.creator_credit: Film Workshop, Seasonal Film Corporation, Tsui Hark and Raymond Lee Wai-Man
results.brief_description: In this rousing martial arts epic set in China during the Ming dynasty (1368-1644), silver-haired eunuchs who control much of the country’s wealth, and murder those who oppose them, kidnap two children. The children are rescued by an Imperial swordsman and his female companion. With the eunuchs’ forces in hot pursuit, the escaping party takes shelter at a mysterious isolated tavern called the Dragon Inn run by a murderous hostess. An atmospherically tense action-drama with spectacular fight sequences and cinematography. Remake of 1966 film “Dragon Inn” (“Longmen Kezhan”) by King Hu. In Cantonese and Mandarin with English subtitles. Cast includes Maggie Cheung, Brigitte Lin, Tony Leung and Donnie Yen.

results.title: New detergents
results.creator_credit: Shell Film Unit and Sarah Erulkar
results.brief_description: Detergents are agents used with water for washing purposes - soap being a common form. Here is explained why a detergent is necessary to effectively remove dirt and grease. New detergents are evolved for special duties and are far more efficient than common soap. Moreover, soap is made from much-needed vegetable oils and fats. These new detergents are made from petroleum wax, so releasing more vegetable oils and natural fats for food. Commentary written by Arthur Calder-Marshall. Music by Lauderic Catous West Indian Orchestra.

results.title: New decimal coin designs
results.brief_description: Designs for Australia’s six new decimal coins prepared by local designer Stuart Devlin, are presented by the Federal Treasurer, Mr. Harold Holt, and a member of the advisory panel on design Mr. Hal Missingham, who worked closely with the designer and helped solve technical problems. The coins feature seven of Australia’s unique fauna- the spiny anteater, lyre-bird, frilled lizard, feather-tailed glider, platypus, kangaroo and emu.

results.title: New deal documentaries: the plow that broke the plains. The River. The Power and the land. The New frontier
results.brief_description: THE PLOW THAT BROKE THE LAND (Dir: Pare Lorentz): The subject is the tragedy of the Dust Bowl in the Midwest - productive land lost through poor management motivated by short term gain - while poetically promoting the conservation and resettlement policies of the New Deal’s farm program. Aimed at a wide audience, this first U.S. government sponsored documentary emphasized the dramatic, ‘a melodrama of nature’ as Lorentz called it, an emotional appeal strengthened by Virgil Thomson’s music score. Lorentz matched his images contrapuntally to Thomson’s symphony of Midwestern themes, achieving intensity through montage. The social militancy contributed by the three photographers was softened by Lorentz. The commercial success of ‘Plow’ led to further films such as Lorentz’s ‘The River’ and Joris Ivens’ The Power and the Land’ designed for widespread theatrical release. Narrated by Thomas Chalmers. THE RIVER (Dir: Pare Lorentz): Following the success of ‘The Plow That Broke the Plains’ the Roosevelt administration financed a follow-up film which was distributed theatrically by Paramount. The theme was again the waste of natural resources through careless and exploitative land management. The focus was specifically on the Mississippi River Basin, the disastrous 1937 flood providing the means of dramatising the issue. The film also promoted New Deal development programs such as the controversial Tennessee Valley Authority. Lorentz further developed the narrative-in-ballad form of ‘The Plow That Broke the Plains’. Free verse with cadenced repetitions, Virgil Thomson’s music score and the dramatic flow of the accomplished camera team came together with a vigour and confidence that is a high-point for the native American documentary school. However, support for the U.S. Film Service, with Lorentz at the head, was short lived, a victim of changing political attitudes. Narrated by Thomas Chalmers. POWER AND THE LAND (Dir: Joris Ivens): The film’s main purpose was to convince American farmers of the necessity for rural electrification through farm cooperatives. It received wide theatrical distribution through RKO. Ivens sought to overcome farmers’ conservatism not by direct appeal but by gentle dramatisation using a family on an Ohio farm and a poetic commentary by Stephen Vincent Benet in a simple before-and-after structure. The hardships of life on a non-electrical farm are contrasted with the benefits brought by electricity. Ivens wrote about the genuine rapport he established with the farming people and his film is a tribute to American ideals and to the hardworking farming families who love the land. A short prologue appears to have been added in the early fifties. Narrated by William P. Adams. THE NEW FRONTIER (Dir: H. B. McClure): H. B. McClure’s film about the Woodlake community offers a forthright, enlightening glimpse into an experimental rural community sponsored by the Federal Emergency Relief Administration, and is perhaps of more historical than stylistic interest. However, Roosevelt’s relief organisations also hired pioneering filmmakers who took the opportunity to create enduring works of poetic yet politically committed cinema. Narrated by Morse Salisbury.

results.title: New day
results.creator_credit: Templar films for Films of Scotland
results.brief_description: The story of Glenrothes, a new town being built in the heart of Fife, Scotland, and of Rothes Colliery, a modern mechanised colliery situated nearby. The pithead facilities at Rothes and the novel architectural design of Glenrothes with its comprehensive amenities for the mining community, are shown and the visit of H.M the Queen and the Duke of Edinburgh to the new town.

results.title: New Dawn Ep. 09
results.brief_description: Last in a series of nine animated films on the history of Western Civilization. Concentrates on the war of liberation in Guinea-Bissau during the 1960s and 1970s, suggesting that through solidarity, co-operation and the ‘people’s union’, other Third World countries would be able to get their freedom and dignity. (English version by the Tricontinental Film Center)

results.title: New dance
results.brief_description: Several short pieces in which individuals or groups of dancers work with the idea of ‘minimal choreography’, using simple props such as balls, rods and firesticks to create complicated patterns and rhythms from a few basic movements. The result is a quirky hybrid of circus skills and dance, augmented by some image manipulation in the edit suite.

results.title: New country - new people
results.brief_description: Describes the original settlement of New Zealand by Europeans, and the various cultures and skills these settlers brought with them. Looks at the lives of present day descendants of these Europeans, and also the more recent migrants to the country.
